Award.AwardTitle: Single-conformation spectroscopy of isolated peptides and synthetic foldamers
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Timothy Zwier of Purdue University and his graduate and undergraduate students are carrying out experimental studies of the conformational preferences and laser-induced isomerization of a series of model peptides, synthetic foldamers, and peptide aggregates, studied either as isolated molecules cooled in a supersonic expansion or as ions cooled to 10K in a cryo-cooled ion trap. Neutral peptides and foldamers are being studied using laser-induced fluorescence (LIF), mass-resolved resonant two-photon ionization (R2PI), IR-UV and UV-UV hole-burning methods to determine the number of conformational isomers present and obtain their single-conformation infrared and ultraviolet spectra. From these spectra, the researchers deduce the preferred intramolecular H-bonding arrangements, discover their unique spectral signatures, provide benchmark tests of the accuracy of calculations, and provide a test bed for emerging methods for quantifying non-bonding interactions in large molecules. Proline-rich alpha-peptides that form loose helices in solution are being studied in isolated form to determine their inherent conformational preferences in the absence of solvent. Synthetic foldamers composed of several types of constrained peptides, prepared collaboratively by the Gellman group, are being studied to test how elongation of the peptide backbone in combination with constraints from cyclic residues, affects the conformational preferences. In expanding these studies to include ions, Professor Zwier and his team are using a newly constructed multi-stage mass spectrometer that incorporates a cryocooled ion trap capable of carrying out single-conformation spectroscopy on larger peptides and peptide aggregates, using photofragment spectroscopy. Here the focus is on longer peptide sequences known in solution to form prototypical secondary structures. Finally, two model peptide hexamers (NNQQNY and VEALYL) composed of sequences that play key roles in amyloid fibril formation, are under investigation as prefibrillar aggregates (oligomer ions containing 2-12 monomers), with the goal of obtaining unique spectroscopic signatures of the early stages of interdigitized beta-sheet formation.

This research project impacts society at large by providing incisive experimental tests of important natural and synthetic structural scaffolds, which can aid theoretical development of next-generation quantum chemical, force field, spectroscopic, and dynamics methods. Specific targets touch on important biophysical problems. Proline-rich alpha-peptides are models for unstructured protein segments. Synthetic foldamers form unique structural scaffolds designed to interact with specific biological receptors of relevance to a wide range of biomedical and drug-discovery applications. The probable role of soluble prefibrillar oligomers in amyloid disease pathogenesis makes them important targets for detailed structural characterization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most molecules of biological interest are large enough to take on many possible shapes for their three-dimensional structures, forming conformational isomers.  While much of biology occurs in aqueous solution at room temperature, the prediction of the structures of biologically relevant molecules from first-principles remains a daunting challenge, with each conformation stabilized by a network of intramolecular and intermolecular hydrogen bonds that often compete with one another.  With the support provided by the NSF, we have carried out fundamental studies of the preferred conformations of three important classes of molecules/molecular aggregates:  (1) neutral peptides and synthetic foldamers, (2) protonated gas phase peptide ions, and (3) aromatic solute-(H2O)n clusters.  Our studies were carried out int he gas phase, undr exotic conditions that bring the molecules with a few degrees of absolute zero in temperature, thereby removing the vastm ajority of their internal energy and trapping them in their low-lying conformational minima.  By removing them from any solvent surroundings, we are able to clearly establish the inherent conformational preferences of the molecules and obtain infrared and ultraviolet spectra that establish the spectroscopic signatures of these prototypical hydrogen-bonded networks.  This provides data of direct importance to those developing computational force fields for peptides and proteins, and tests the ability of first--principles calculations to predict their structures and vibrational frequencies. 

Our efforts have been rewarded by new and unexpected insights to the types of folded structures preferred by the molecules we've studied.  For instance, our study of a series of polyglycine peptides with varying length showed that this, the most flexible of amino acids, folds in the absence of solvent preferentially into a 124/16 mixed helix in which 14-membered H-bonded rings and 16-membered rings point in opposite directions along  the peptide backbone, thereby minimizing the asymmetric charge distribution in the molecule (its permanent dipole moment).

We have also engaged in a fruitful collaboration with Prof. Sam Gellman and his group at UW-Madison, a world leader in synthesizing peptidomimetic biopolymers designed to fold in specific ways (called 'synthetic foldamers').  In a series of papers coming out of that work, we have shown that the design constraints Gellman built into the non-natural portion of the peptide sequence are robust enough in their folding preferences to stabilize the foldamer in its preferred helical form already in the shortest sequence it is possible to do so.

Using a custom-built multi-stage mass spectrometer constructed previously with NSF funds (via an NSF CRIF Instrumentation Development grant, NSF CHE-0820766 in collaboration with Professor Scott McLuckey at Purdue), we have extended our single-conformation laser spectroscopy to the study of cryocooled gas phase peptide ions.  At its most fundamental level, the initial results from this new instrument address the important question of whether the presence of a charge in a peptide disrupts local secondary structure inthe peptide backbone, or enhances it.  Using the prototypical protonated pentapeptide [YGGFL+H]+ and itsmethoxy-capped derivative, [YGGFL-OMe+H]+, we have shown that both ions fole into a beta-hairpin structure in which the charge on the protonated N-terminus (NH3+) stabilizes the beta-hairpin by sitting atop the turn and forming H_boneds to amide groups that otherwise would not have H-bonds to them.

Finally, while our primary focus has been on isolated neutral and protonated biomolecules without solvent present, the collisional cooling present in our gas-phase supersonic expansion also makes it possible to synthesize molecular clusters composed of a solvent molecule surrounded by a controlled number of solvent molecules.  Because H2O is nature's solvent, we have studied a series of prototypical aromatic solutes, including bnzene, 1,2-diphenoxyethane, and [2.2.2]paracyclophane, clustered with from one to severn water molecules attached.  This molecular-scale view of solvation of prototypical aromatic molecules enable us to directly probe the hydrogen-bonded networks formed by the water molecules, as viewed by the way in which their OH bond vibrations respond to H-bond formation.  OUr OH stretch infrared spectra then probe these H-bonds, shedding light on how they are perturbed in the presence of the aromatic solute, and direclty observing the effects of that aromatic-H2O binding vian an OH hydrogen bond to the aromatic pi cloud of the solute.
